<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 118, 379, 142]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 194, 332, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 247, 507, 263]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 277, 489, 322]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 338, 228, 353]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 354, 880, 522]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(10 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 549, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 565, 571, 612]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 97, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 720, 720, 738]]<|/det|>
A scientist examines a rock which has been brought back from the Moon.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 750, 366, 768]]<|/det|>
He measures three quantities.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 780, 410, 798]]<|/det|>
1 the density of the rock

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 833, 405, 851]]<|/det|>

<label>A</label>

1 and 2 only B 1 and 3 only C 2 and 3 only D 1, 2 and 3

anticlockwise momentclockwise moment

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 755, 97, 774]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 755, 892, 772]]<|/det|> A spacecraft is travelling in space with no resultant force and no resultant moment acting on it. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 785, 522, 803]]<|/det|> Which statement about the spacecraft is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 813, 138, 831]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 813, 354, 831]]<|/det|> Its direction is changing. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 840, 138, 858]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 840, 304, 858]]<|/det|> It is in equilibrium. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 867, 133, 885]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 867, 351, 885]]<|/det|> Its speed is decreasing. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 893, 133, 911]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 893, 344, 911]]<|/det|> Its speed is increasing.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 836, 91]]<|/det|> The graph shows the total energy transferred by an electric motor over a period of time. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 787, 121]]<|/det|> In which region of the graph is the greatest power being developed by the motor? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[275, 129, 720, 310]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 336, 96, 355]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 336, 571, 355]]<|/det|> Electrical energy may be obtained from nuclear fission. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 367, 576, 384]]<|/det|> In which order is the energy transferred in this process? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 396, 134, 415]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 396, 658, 415]]<|/det|> nuclear fuel \(\rightarrow\) generator \(\rightarrow\) reactor and boiler \(\rightarrow\) turbines <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 425, 134, 443]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 425, 658, 443]]<|/det|> nuclear fuel \(\rightarrow\) generator \(\rightarrow\) turbines \(\rightarrow\) reactor and boiler <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 452, 133, 470]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 452, 658, 470]]<|/det|> nuclear fuel \(\rightarrow\) reactor and boiler \(\rightarrow\) generator \(\rightarrow\) turbines <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 479, 133, 497]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 479, 658, 497]]<|/det|> nuclear fuel \(\rightarrow\) reactor and boiler \(\rightarrow\) turbines \(\rightarrow\) generator <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 522, 96, 541]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 522, 771, 541]]<|/det|> The diagram shows an electric circuit. When the switch is closed, the lamp is lit. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 555, 591, 650]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 662, 920, 697]]<|/det|> Which row states the type of energy stored in the cell and how this energy is usefully transferred to the lamp? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 707, 668, 855]]<|/det|>
type of energy
stored in the cell		how this energy is usefully transferred to the lamp
Achemicalby electric current
Bchemicalby light
Celectricalby electric current
Delectricalby light

work donetime taken

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 471, 106, 490]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 470, 870, 490]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a ray of light in glass incident on the surface between the glass and air. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[351, 500, 641, 621]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 631, 858, 651]]<|/det|> What happens if the angle of incidence is made larger than the critical angle for the glass? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 661, 138, 679]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 661, 531, 680]]<|/det|> The angle of refraction becomes equal to \(90^{\circ}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 688, 133, 705]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 688, 643, 707]]<|/det|> There is a refracted ray and a ray reflected inside the glass. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 714, 133, 733]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 714, 390, 733]]<|/det|> There is a refracted ray only. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 740, 133, 759]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 740, 522, 759]]<|/det|> There is only a ray reflected inside the glass. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 785, 106, 803]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 784, 920, 817]]<|/det|> Radiation from which part of the electromagnetic spectrum is used in the remote controller for a television? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 828, 134, 846]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 828, 277, 846]]<|/det|> infrared waves <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 855, 136, 873]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 855, 255, 873]]<|/det|> microwaves <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 882, 136, 900]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 882, 255, 900]]<|/det|> radio waves <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 907, 134, 925]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 907, 292, 925]]<|/det|> ultraviolet waves

Dthe samethe same
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 303, 106, 322]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 303, 284, 321]]<|/det|> What is ultrasound? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 332, 133, 350]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 332, 675, 350]]<|/det|> sound waves that are so loud that they damage human hearing <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 357, 133, 376]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 357, 630, 376]]<|/det|> sound waves that are too high-pitched for humans to hear <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 384, 133, 403]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 384, 623, 403]]<|/det|> sound waves that are too low-pitched for humans to hear <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 411, 133, 429]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 411, 569, 428]]<|/det|> sound waves that are too quiet for humans to hear <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 454, 104, 473]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 454, 603, 472]]<|/det|> A bar magnet is brought near to a rod of unknown material. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 484, 623, 502]]<|/det|> The unknown rod is attracted to both ends of the bar magnet. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[331, 512, 665, 670]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 682, 428, 699]]<|/det|> Which material is the rod made from? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 710, 134, 728]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 710, 240, 727]]<|/det|> aluminium <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 737, 133, 755]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 737, 297, 755]]<|/det|> magnetised steel <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 764, 133, 782]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 764, 308, 781]]<|/det|> unmagnetised iron <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 790, 133, 808]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 790, 210, 807]]<|/det|> plastic

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 384, 709, 403]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 443, 636, 460]]<|/det|>
The live wire may become loose and touch the metal case.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 470, 134, 488]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 470, 789, 488]]<|/det|>
If the metal case becomes live, the earth wire conducts current to the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 496, 131, 515]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 496, 544, 515]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 522, 792, 540]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 565, 591, 583]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 641, 248, 658]]<|/det|>
Who is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 670, 134, 687]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 670, 269, 687]]<|/det|>
both students

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 696, 134, 714]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 696, 280, 714]]<|/det|>
neither student

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 723, 133, 740]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 723, 272, 740]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 749, 133, 766]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 749, 272, 766]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 551, 106, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>37</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 551, 853, 570]]<|/det|>
A very important experiment improved scientists' understanding of the structure of matter.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 583, 655, 602]]<|/det|>
The experiment involved \(\alpha\) -particles being fired at a thin, gold foil.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 613, 262, 631]]<|/det|>
What happened?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 643, 134, 661]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 643, 688, 661]]<|/det|>
All the \(\alpha\) -particles were absorbed by the nuclei of the gold atoms.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 670, 133, 689]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 670, 591, 689]]<|/det|>
All the \(\alpha\) -particles were unaffected by the gold atoms.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 698, 133, 715]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 698, 858, 715]]<|/det|>
Some of the \(\alpha\) -particles were attracted by the neutrons in the nuclei of the gold atoms.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 725, 133, 743]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 725, 843, 743]]<|/det|>
Some of the \(\alpha\) -particles were repelled by the protons in the nuclei of the gold atoms.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 768, 106, 787]]<|/det|>
<label>38</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 768, 841, 787]]<|/det|>
Some sources of background radiation are natural and others are due to human activity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 798, 324, 816]]<|/det|>
Which source is natural?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 826, 134, 845]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 826, 280, 845]]<|/det|>
medical X-rays

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 854, 133, 872]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 854, 356, 872]]<|/det|>
nuclear weapons testing

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 880, 133, 898]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 880, 465, 898]]<|/det|>
radioactive waste from power stations

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 907, 133, 925]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 907, 331, 925]]<|/det|>
radon gas from rocks

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 104, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 510, 89]]<|/det|>
A radioactive material is placed near a detector.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 569, 120]]<|/det|>
The detector shows a count rate of 28 000 counts / min.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 131, 920, 166]]<|/det|>
When a piece of card is put between the material and the counter, the reading decreases to 25 000 counts / min.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 177, 920, 210]]<|/det|>
When an aluminium sheet is put between the material and the counter, the reading remains at 25 000 counts / min.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 222, 920, 255]]<|/det|>
When a sheet of lead is put between the material and the counter, the reading decreases to 19 000 counts / min.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 267, 529, 285]]<|/det|>
What is being emitted by the radioactive material?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 297, 134, 314]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 297, 314, 314]]<|/det|>
\(\alpha , \beta\) and \(\gamma \)-radiation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 324, 134, 343]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 324, 336, 342]]<|/det|>
\(\alpha\) and \(\beta\)-radiation only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 351, 134, 369]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 351, 333, 369]]<|/det|>
\(\alpha\) and \(\gamma\)-radiation only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 378, 133, 396]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 378, 331, 396]]<|/det|>
\(\beta\) and \(\gamma\)-radiation only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 421, 102, 440]]<|/det|>
<label>40</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 421, 497, 440]]<|/det|>
A radioactive isotope has a half-life of 3 years.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 452, 623, 470]]<|/det|>
A sample gives a count rate of 100 counts / min on a detector.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 482, 655, 500]]<|/det|>
Which calculation is used to predict the count rate after 12 years?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 514, 134, 533]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 512, 336, 536]]<|/det|>
100 \(\times \frac{1}{2} \times \frac{1}{2} \times \frac{1}{2} \times \frac{1}{2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 553, 134, 572]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 552, 297, 575]]<|/det|>
100 \(\times \frac{1}{2} \times \frac{1}{2} \times \frac{1}{2}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 593, 134, 612]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 593, 225, 615]]<|/det|>
100 \(\times \frac{3}{12}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 632, 134, 651]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 632, 268, 655]]<|/det|>
100 \(\times \frac{12}{3} \times \frac{1}{2}\)
